vignette: Leroy is a 34 year old male, whose chief complaint is, “I am having intrusive thoughts.” Leroy reports that “since childhood, I have been experiencing intrusive thoughts.” He reports he has met with a number of psychiatrists in the past, and has tried a range of different psychiatric medications. Leroy reports he was recently recommended by his present physician to see a psychiatrist again, given how distressing his intrusive thoughts have become. His previous psychiatrist started him on Zoloft, and gave him recommendation for community based mental health psychotherapist.  Leroy has been taking the Zoloft (200 mg daily) for about 5 years, for what he states his provider thought was “anxiety or depression.” Leroy acknowledges history of periods of “sadness”, stating “yeah sad, sometimes, but not depressed; when things get out of control; its been a while though; when something feels out of reach.” Denied present or past suicidal ideation, and denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Leroy insists no problems with perceptual distortion or paranoia, and denied thought insertion or thought broadcasting.  Leroy stated that the intrusive thoughts, “first started happening when I was a kid, I was able to cope with them; getting better understanding what they were; ways to get them to go away; calm myself down and regain control and go on with my life; now that is not working.” Leroy states the most recent intrusive thought has been a fear that the chart bus he drives from his local airport to downtown stop will “slide off the road because of ice or snow.” He thinks about this, on average, about 30 to 45 minutes a day.  Leroy endorsed episodes of “panic” and “my body almost feels like its paralyzed; I experience pain from my spine up”, which lasts for a couple of days at a time. With regards to “generalized anxiety”, patient reports “I would have these thoughts about my ailing mother; she has schizophrenia; my body would react to whatever I was thinking about her; my body tenses up when that happens.” Leroy denied any preoccupations about his physical health, nor inability to leave the home because of anxiety. He reports to work regularly, and rarely misses any work unless he is very sick. He says he is never late to work or planned appointments. Leroy has a girlfriend, and says that relationship is going “great.” In his spare time, he continues to join his friends for basketball pickup games and video game nights, which he still enjoys. Leroy does remember a feeling of having to tap the door handle a few times before he opens it, but said this never lasted more than a few second and was not associated with any fear of catastrophic consequences if he did not complete the task.  Leroy acknowledges observed violence/abuse of his parents when growing up, and with harsh parenting to his 3 siblings, patient denied problems with flashbacks, nightmares or hypervigilance associated with the trauma. Patient works second shift, gets home around 1:30 a.m., reports falling asleep at 2:30 a.m. and wakes up at 10/11 a.m., and can typically sleep through the night without interruption. He reports his energy level is “normal through the week.” Denied recent or past mania. Reports contributing stressors are “work --- not the most peaceful environment.” Also reports mother suffers from “type of schizophrenia and for a while she was taking medication and just recently now decided to stop; that’s been going on for quite some time.” Leroy’s urine toxicology returned with marijuana, and TSH level was within normal limits.
diagnosis: Obsessive compulsive disorder (F42.8)
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette to arrive at the most appropriate diagnoses.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 34-year-old male
- Works as a charter bus driver
- Has a girlfriend (relationship going well)
- Maintains social activities (basketball, video games with friends)

Chief Complaint:
- "I am having intrusive thoughts"

History of Present Illness:
- Intrusive thoughts since childhood
- Currently distressing enough to warrant psychiatric re-evaluation
- On Sertraline (Zoloft) 200mg daily for 5 years for "anxiety or depression"
- Main intrusive thought: fear that his charter bus will "slide off the road because of ice or snow"
- Spends 30-45 minutes daily thinking about this
- Previous coping mechanisms no longer working

Psychiatric Symptoms:
1. Intrusive thoughts (since childhood, now worsening)
2. Episodes of "panic" with physical symptoms (body feels paralyzed, pain from spine up) lasting "a couple of days at a time"
3. Generalized anxiety related to mother's health - body tenses up
4. History of tapping door handles before opening (brief, not associated with feared consequences)
5. Periods of "sadness" - contextual, not meeting criteria for depression ("when things get out of control")

Negative/Denied Symptoms:
- Denies current or past suicidal ideation
- Denies harm to self/others
- Denies perceptual disturbances, paranoia
- Denies thought insertion or broadcasting
- Denies health preoccupations
- Denies agoraphobia
- Denies flashbacks, nightmares, hypervigilance related to childhood trauma
- Denies mania
- No sleep problems (sleeps 2:30am-10/11am, appropriate for second shift)
- Energy level "normal"

Psychosocial:
- Childhood trauma: witnessed violence/abuse between parents, harsh parenting to siblings


- Current stressors include an unsettling work environment and mother's recent medication discontinuation for her schizophrenia diagnosis
- Family history significant for maternal schizophrenia

Functioning:
- Maintains employment with reliable attendance and punctuality
- Sustains romantic relationship
- Participates in recreational activities with peers
- Continues to find pleasure in hobbies

Substances:
- Marijuana detected on urine drug screen

Medical:
- TSH within normal limits

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

1. **Generalized Anxiety Disorder (F41.1):**
The patient presents with worry that is difficult to control (intrusive thoughts about bus sliding off road, concerns about mother's health). He spends 30-45 minutes daily on these worry thoughts. Physical symptoms include muscle tension ("body tenses up"). This has been ongoing since childhood. However, the worry is somewhat specific (not generalized across multiple domains). The pattern of specific feared catastrophes is more consistent with OCD or specific phobia.

2. **Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (F42.2):**
The patient has intrusive, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) about his bus sliding off the road due to ice/snow. He mentions having these thoughts 30-45 minutes daily (meets the criterion for significant time). History of door-handle tapping (possible compulsion), though brief and not associated with feared consequences. The intrusive thoughts are ego-dystonic and distressing. However, there's limited evidence of clear compulsions to neutralize the obsessions. This could be primarily obsess

ional OCD. The panic-like episodes he describes—where his body feels paralyzed with spine pain lasting a couple of days—don't align with typical panic attack presentations, which resolve within minutes. These seem more like sustained anxiety episodes. Regarding the positive marijuana screen, insufficient details exist about frequency, consequences, or dependence criteria to establish a substance use disorder diagnosis. An adjustment disorder with anxiety could apply if stressors are recent and the symptoms are temporally related to identifiable life changes.

However, his anxiety symptoms trace back to childhood, well before current stressors like his mother's illness or work pressures. PTSD doesn't fit despite his childhood exposure to violence and abuse, since he denies the core features of flashbacks, nightmares, and hypervigilance.

The most compelling diagnosis appears to be generalized anxiety disorder—he's experienced pervasive worry since childhood, maintains physical tension, struggles to control anxious thoughts, and the specific worry about the bus combined with concerns about his mother suggests a broader anxiety pattern rather than isolated fears. He functions adequately but remains significantly distressed. OCD remains a secondary consideration given the possible obsessional quality of his bus-related worry. The patient's language around "intrusive thoughts" and the specific content—worrying the bus will slide off the road—points toward obsessional thinking. The door tapping history suggests ritualistic behavior, though he didn't report feared consequences tied to it, which complicates whether true compulsions are present. Weighing the evidence, the anxiety appears multifaceted: obsessional features dominate, but there's also generalized worry about his mother and atypical panic episodes. Given this mixed presentation, Generalized Anxiety Disorder captures the broader pattern of persistent worry and chronic course more comprehensively than OCD alone.

However, the intrusive thoughts terminology and catastrophic content with childhood onset are compelling for OCD—the 30-45 minutes daily spent on these thoughts meets the time threshold. Panic episodes are documented, though their duration is unusual. Cannabis use is confirmed on toxicology but doesn't meet criteria for a use disorder based on available information. The remaining anxiety symptoms that don't fit neatly into the primary diagnoses might warrant an unspecified or other specified anxiety disorder code.

I should reconsider which diagnosis truly anchors this case. The patient's specific language and presentation suggest OCD warrants primary consideration. The intrusive thoughts about catastrophic accidents while driving represent a classic harm obsession, and the door-tapping behavior hints at compulsive patterns. He's already on maximum-dose Zoloft, the first-line treatment for OCD. The childhood onset and persistent nature further support this. While generalized worry about his mother with accompanying physical tension indicates GAD features, the intrusive thoughts remain the chief complaint and longest-standing concern.

OCD should be the primary diagnosis, followed by the other conditions in order of clinical significance. but not quite 1 hour. The 30-45 minute range still represents substantial time involvement with significant distress and functional consequences, which can support an OCD diagnosis even if slightly below the typical threshold.

I'm settling on OCD as a primary diagnosis alongside generalized anxiety, panic disorder, cannabis use, and other specified anxiety disorder. Though I should reconsider whether those panic episodes fit the typical presentation—the patient describes them lasting several days with physical symptoms, which seems atypical for standard panic attacks. Considering his childhood trauma history, an unspecified trauma- and stressor-related disorder could apply, though he hasn't endorsed typical PTSD symptoms. Ultimately, OCD appears to be the primary diagnosis given his presenting complaint, early-onset course, specific obsessional themes, and prior treatment responses. The differential should prioritize generalized anxiety disorder for his excessive worry and somatic tension, cannabis use based on positive screening, and possibly panic disorder despite the atypical presentation of his episodes. Other specified anxiety disorder might capture his limited symptom anxiety attacks more precisely than a standard panic diagnosis.

vignette: Emil is a 22 year old male that reports “my mom wanted us to meet because she spent her whole first therapy session talking to another therapist at her new program about how she feels I need help; I suspect it has to do with my multiple sclerosis (MS), recently losing my fiancé (Lizzy), and after loosing my dog that came with my fiancé. I also lost my career as a farmer.” The patient reports “My girlfriend and I had a good relationship when I used to be able to fish with her; she was a blue blood from the Cape.” Patient reports that he survived being “attacked when I was at a local bar about 4 years ago; the guy smashed a few beer bottles on my head; I had to go to the hospital and they did brain scans; I don’t remember what they said they found.” Patient reports that after that attack, he stopped fishing and started drinking alcohol heavily, at least 8 standard drinks per day, resulting in him missing work, the end of his relationship with his girlfriend, and resulted in getting two DUIs. Patient remembers, “I tried cutting down, but I was never able to do it.” The patient has been sober from alcohol for 76 days now. He denied any other drug use. Patient reports that around two years ago, “I was starting having another MS flare, I stopped being able to sleep for about two weeks and felt angry all the time.” Patient reports during that time he took several last minute trips to Baltimore by train, trying to start a new business and during that time had many sexual indiscretions. He states “people said I was acting strange and that I claimed I was a celebrity that was going to find a cure for autism.” Emil states “I felt like I had endless energy and could take on the world.” The patient reports no similar episodes like that since then, and denied any major mood symptoms since that time. Emil denied recent or past hallucinations, paranoia or thought insertion. Emil reports he never experienced trauma, with the exception of losing his girlfriend and dog. The patient denied any recent problems with depressed, sad, or hopeless mood, and denied problems recent problems with decreased need for sleep and associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or feelings of euphoria. He denied recent or past anxiety or panic, nor OCD.
diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, most recent episode manic, in remission (F31.74), Alcohol use disorder, initial remission (F10.21), Mood disorder due to a known physiologic condition with manic features (F06.33)
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette to extract relevant information and develop a differential diagnosis.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 22-year-old male named Emil

Chief Complaint:
- Mother concerned about his mental health, brought to attention through her own therapy
- Multiple stressors: MS diagnosis, loss of fiancé, loss of dog, loss of career as farmer

Psychiatric History:

1. Traumatic Brain Injury/Head Trauma (4 years ago):
- Attacked at a bar, beer bottles smashed on his head
- Required hospitalization and brain scans
- Doesn't remember what they found

2. Alcohol Use Disorder (following the attack, 4 years ago):
- Heavy drinking: at least 8 standard drinks per day
- Consequences: missed work, end of relationship, two DUIs
- Tried to cut down but unable to
- Currently sober for 76 days
- No other drug use reported

3. Manic Episode (approximately 2 years ago):
- Triggered around an MS flare
- Duration: approximately 2 weeks
- Symptoms:
  - Insomnia/decreased need for sleep
  - Irritability ("angry all the time")
  - Increased goal-directed activity (impulsive trips to Baltimore, trying to start a new business)
  - Sexual indiscretions (hypersexuality)
  - Grandiosity (claimed to be a celebrity, said he would find a cure for autism)
  - Increased energy ("endless energy," "could take on the world")
  - Others noted he was "acting strange"

4. Current Mental Status:
- No current mood symptoms
- No current manic symptoms
- Denies hallucinations, paranoia, thought insertion (current or past)
- Denies anxiety, panic, OCD
- Denies trauma history except relationship losses

Medical History:
- Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
- History of head trauma with brain scans (results unknown)


---

The manic episode from two years ago clearly fits the diagnostic criteria for mania—it lasted two weeks with prominent decreased need for sleep, grandiose beliefs, increased goal-directed activity, and risky sexual behavior that caused noticeable impairment. The key diagnostic question is whether this represents primary bipolar disorder or a secondary mood disturbance related to his MS or prior head trauma. The temporal relationship to an MS flare suggests a possible organic etiology, though MS-related mania is relatively uncommon. His significant head trauma with unknown imaging results also raises the possibility of neurological contribution to mood dysregulation.

His alcohol use clearly meets criteria for a moderate to severe disorder—consuming eight drinks daily, multiple failed attempts at abstinence, and substantial consequences including legal problems and relationship breakdown. He's now 76 days sober, indicating early remission. The recent losses of his fiancé, dog, and career represent significant psychosocial stressors that warrant consideration of an adjustment or trauma-related disorder, though he denies current mood symptoms beyond what might be expected from these circumstances.

The head trauma history with hospitalization and imaging is also relevant—neurocognitive impairment from traumatic brain injury could contribute to his presentation and should be ruled out. For coding purposes, Bipolar I Disorder in remission would be F31.74 if fully remitted or F31.73 if partially remitted. The alcohol use disorder codes as F10.21 in early remission. If the MS is deemed contributory to the manic episode, that would code separately as F06.33 or F06.34 depending on feature presentation.

The critical diagnostic consideration is determining whether his manic episode was a primary bipolar condition or secondary to the MS flare-up. The temporal relationship between the MS exacerbation and mood symptoms suggests the latter may be more accurate, though both diagnoses warrant consideration in the differential.

For the substance use component, alcohol dependence with severe features in early remission is clearly documented. The head trauma history and cumulative losses also point toward potential neurocognitive sequelae and adjustment difficulties that should be captured diagnostically. The primary question remains whether to code this as Bipolar I Disorder or as a secondary mood disorder attributable to the underlying neurological condition. d Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (MS), with manic features (F06.33) - as an alternative if the MS flare is deemed the primary etiology. However, listing both Bipolar I and this diagnosis for the same episode creates diagnostic redundancy, so I need to choose one primary approach.

The cleaner formulation would be: Bipolar I Disorder, most recent episode manic, in full remission (F31.74) as the primary diagnosis, followed by Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission (F10.21), then Unspecified Anxiety Disorder (F41.9) to account for the anxiety symptoms without over-specifying. I should also note the Mild Neurocognitive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury (F06.70) given the documented head trauma history, and consider whether the trauma and losses warrant an additional stressor-related diagnosis. Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe, In Early Remission (F10.21) - Multiple criteria present including failed reduction attempts and significant consequences, with 76 days of sobriety marking early recovery. Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (MS), with manic features (F06.33) - The temporal relationship between the MS exacerbation and manic presentation warrants consideration as a potential medical etiology. Unspecified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder (F43.9) - Addresses the cumulative impact of recent losses including the relationship dissolution, pet death, and career disruption. Mild Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Traumatic Brain Injury, without behavioral disturbance (F06.70) - The prior head trauma with hospitalization could contribute to cognitive changes. I'm recognizing that listing both Bipolar I and the medical condition-related bipolar disorder creates redundancy—they're competing explanations for the same manic episode, so I need to determine which better accounts for the clinical presentation. I, current or most recent episode, hypomanic, in full remission. F31.74 correctly captures Bipolar I disorder with the most recent manic episode now in full remission.

For the alcohol use disorder code, I need to verify the severity and remission status mapping. F10.20 denotes moderate severity without remission, while F10.21 indicates moderate severity in remission. The mild category uses F10.10 and F10.11 respectively.

The bipolar and related disorder due to another medical condition with manic features (F06.33) and unspecified trauma-related disorder (F43.9) are both appropriate. For the neurocognitive disorder secondary to TBI, F06.70 applies when there's no behavioral disturbance, with F06.71 used if behavioral symptoms are present. I'm reconsidering whether mild neurocognitive disorder is the most accurate diagnosis given the clinical presentation.

The patient hasn't reported cognitive difficulties—we only know a head injury occurred. Without documented cognitive impairment, diagnosing a neurocognitive disorder may be premature. Similarly, while he's experienced significant losses, he denies depressed mood and doesn't describe emotional or behavioral symptoms that would meet adjustment disorder criteria. His mother's concerns don't necessarily align with his own reported experience. I need to focus on what's actually present in his presentation rather than what might be speculated.

The assault at the bar followed by behavioral changes—heavy drinking, withdrawing from activities like fishing—suggests a possible trauma response, even though he minimizes the event. This could warrant an unspecified trauma- and stressor-related disorder. His multiple medical conditions, particularly MS, are also relevant to consider. For the fifth diagnosis, personality change secondary to TBI or MS might be appropriate, though he denies depressive symptoms, which limits that differential.

Given his explicit denial of trauma symptoms and that his drinking is already captured under alcohol use disorder, I'm leaning toward mild neurocognitive disorder from the documented head trauma as a more defensible fifth diagnosis. The bar assault doesn't seem to meet threshold for a formal stress disorder in his presentation. Between unspecified depressive disorder, anxiety, and adjustment disorder—all of which he denies having—none fit as well as considering the cognitive effects of his brain injury.

My final five diagnoses are: Bipolar I Disorder in full remission, severe alcohol use disorder in early remission, bipolar and related disorder secondary to MS with manic features, unspecified trauma and stressor-related disorder, and mild neurocognitive disorder from the TBI. The critical question is whether his mania stems primarily from bipolar illness or from the MS flare itself—the temporal association with his MS exacerbation and MS's known capacity to trigger secondary mania makes this distinction essential to clarify. itive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury, without behavioral disturbance (F06.70)

The TBI history warrants inclusion given the documented cognitive effects, though it's mild and not currently causing significant behavioral issues. This completes the diagnostic picture alongside the primary mood disorder and substance use considerations.

2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21

4. Unspecified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - F43.9

vignette: Neveah is a 14 year old girl that comes to her pediatrician with her mother (presently 4 months pregnant) due to “out of control behaviors at home.” The patient appears restless in the exam room and requiring redirection from her mother throughout the visit. The patient frequently punches her mother in the legs, and in the stomach, and the patient even threw her ipad at the pediatrician when she asked the patient what was upsetting her. Most of the patients psychiatric history is gathered from her mother, given how irritable the patient is during the exam. The mother reports Neveah was born 8 weeks pre-mature, spent about 1 month in the neonatal intensive care unit due to problems with breathing, and ultimately discharged home to her care at one month of age. The patient met developmental milestones on or near expected time, and was “clingy” when she was a toddler, but had no problems making friends in daycare and grade school. When patient was about 11 years of age, her biological father left the home to join the military, and has deployed ever since. Around 12 years of age, around summertime, the patient appeared much more talkative, energetic, and would go several days only needing about 3 hours of sleep at night. She was more impulsive during these times, and believed she had super powers to “make her friends get in trouble at school”, even when she was not at school herself. She was never tired the following day. During that same period, she had many temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day of the week, that seemed disproportionate to circumstances, like having to have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich instead of a peanut butter and fluff sandwich. The tantrums would last several hours in a day. This pattern of behavior would last for several weeks at a time, with periods of months returning to normal mood and behavior. The patient never appeared to be hallucination or responding to internal stimuli, and never appeared sad or depressed. Neveah had to be hospitalized during an episode like this when she was 13 years old. Neveah refuses to take medications for her symptoms. The start of this year academic year, that patient appeared more calm and in good behavioral control, but began to have similar symptoms of irritability, violence at home, not needing to sleep, talking fast, and property destruction at home.
diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, current episode manic (F31.2)
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette to develop a differential diagnosis.

**Key Clinical Information Extracted:**

Demographics:
- 14-year-old female
- Mother is currently 4 months pregnant (potential stressor)

Presenting Problem:
- "Out of control behaviors at home"
- Restless in exam room
- Physical aggression (punching mother in legs and stomach)
- Property destruction (threw iPad at pediatrician)
- Highly irritable during exam

Developmental/Birth History:
- Born 8 weeks premature
- 1 month in NICU for breathing problems
- Met developmental milestones on or near expected time
- "Clingy" as toddler but no problems making friends

Relevant History:
- Father left home when patient was 11 to join military, deployed since
- Mother currently pregnant (potential stressor - new sibling)

Psychiatric History - Episode Pattern:

**First notable episode around age 12 (summertime):**
- Much more talkative
- Increased energy
- Decreased need for sleep (only 3 hours/night for several days)
- NOT tired the following day
- Increased impulsivity
- Grandiose delusions: believed she had "super powers to make her friends get in trouble at school" even when not at school
- Multiple temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day
- Tantrums disproportionate to circumstances
- Tantrums lasted several hours per day
- Episode lasted several weeks
- Periods of months with return to normal mood and behavior

**Hospitalization at age 13** for similar episode

**Current episode (start of academic year):**
- Had period of being calm and good behavioral control
- Now experiencing:
  - Irritability
  - Violence at home
  - Decreased need for sleep
  - Rapid speech
  - Property destruction

**Negative symptoms:**
- Never appeared to be hallucinating or responding to internal stimuli


- No depressive symptoms noted during evaluations

**Treatment:**
- Refuses to take medications

**Differential Diagnosis Analysis:**

1. **Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic** (F31.1-F31.2)
This diagnosis fits the clinical picture well. The pattern shows distinct episodes separated by months of normal functioning, with each episode featuring decreased sleep without fatigue, elevated talkativeness, increased energy, and psychotic-level grandiosity (believing she has super powers). She's had multiple episodes across three separate years, and the current presentation mirrors previous manic episodes with irritability, aggression, and decreased sleep need. The delusional belief about her powers causing peer conflicts even when absent indicates psychotic features within the manic episode.

2. **Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD)** (F34.81)
While severe temper outbursts occurring multiple times weekly with persistent irritability between episodes could suggest DMDD, several factors argue against it. The episodic pattern with complete baseline recovery for months contradicts DMDD's chronic course. Additionally, the decreased sleep need, rapid speech, and grandiose delusions aren't features of DMDD. The onset also appears after age 10, which doesn't meet DMDD criteria.

3. **Bipolar II Disorder** - Less likely because the episodes appear to meet full criteria for mania (not just hypomania) - particularly the psychotic features (grandiose delusions), hospitalization required, and severity of impairment.

4. **Oppositional Defiant Behavior** (F91.3)
Angry mood, argumentative behavior, and vindictiveness are present, but these should not be diagnosed separately if they occur exclusively during mood episodes.

5. **Conduct Disorder** (F91.1 or F91.2)
Physical aggression and property destruction occur, yet again, if these behaviors are confined to mood episodes, a separate diagnosis isn't appropriate.

6. **ADHD** - The impulsivity and restlessness could suggest this, but the episodic nature with clear periods of normal functioning argues against primary ADHD. The pattern of distinct episodes with symptom-free intervals doesn't align with ADHD's persistent course.

7. **Adjustment Disorder** - While stressors like the father's departure and mother's pregnancy are present, the symptom presentation doesn't match this diagnosis well.

8. **Intermittent Explosive Disorder** (F63.81) - Aggressive outbursts might point here, but the accompanying mood symptoms (reduced sleep need, increased speech, grandiosity, elevated energy) better explain this as bipolar disorder rather than a primary aggression disorder.

The episodic presentation with distinct manic features—decreased sleep need, increased talkativeness, grandiose delusions about possessing superpowers, impulsivity, and heightened energy—combined with psychotic symptoms, clear periods of normal functioning between episodes, and the need for hospitalization across multiple occurrences points to Bipolar I Disorder as the primary diagnosis.

Secondary considerations include unspecified or other specified bipolar presentations if diagnostic criteria aren't fully met, DMDD though age criteria may not align, ODD and conduct disorder if symptoms extend beyond mood episodes, and intermittent explosive disorder as a less likely alternative given the broader mood episode context. The episodic presentation with manic symptoms and grandiose delusions points clearly to Bipolar I Disorder, current episode manic with psychotic features as the primary diagnosis. For comorbid or differential considerations, Conduct Disorder fits given the aggression and property destruction, while Oppositional Defiant Disorder could apply if defiant patterns persist outside manic episodes. ADHD warrants consideration due to impulsivity, though the episodic nature makes this less likely than the mood disorder explanation. 91.3
4. Conduct Disorder, adolescent-onset type - F91.2
5. Intermittent Explosive Disorder - F63.81

The conduct disorder diagnosis fits given the onset around age 12, which aligns with the adolescent-onset specifier. The final diagnostic formulation captures the mood dysregulation, behavioral disturbances, and impulse control issues across multiple domains.
model_diagnosis:
1. Bipolar I Disorder, current episode manic, with psychotic features - F31.2
2. Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder - F34.81
3. Oppositional Defiant Disorder - F91.3
4. Conduct Disorder, adolescent-onset type - F91.2
5. Intermittent Explosive Disorder - F63.81

vignette: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.
diagnosis: Acute stress disorder (F43.0)
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette and extract the relevant information to formulate a differential diagnosis.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 63-year-old female
- Mother of 5 children, 12 grandchildren

Chief Complaint: "I'm hallucinating"

Timeline:
- Symptoms began 27 days ago (less than 1 month, but essentially around 1 month)
- Precipitating event: Witnessed a pedestrian struck by a vehicle, attempted to help with CPR, pedestrian died at the scene

Current Symptoms:
1. Persistent feelings of "dread" and "anxiety" every day since the event
2. Exaggerated startle response - "jumps out of skin" when hearing car wheels skid (hyperarousal)
3. Intrusive images of the pedestrian laying in the street at work - "can't get the images out of my head" (intrusion symptoms)
4. Nightmares related to the event - wakes 2-3 times per night (intrusion symptoms, sleep disturbance)
5. Avoidance of driving for fear of being in a car accident (avoidance)
6. Dissociative experience described: "felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desk, as if I was hovering from above" - this is depersonalization/derealization

Pertinent Negatives:
- No history of depression or mania
- Was in usual state of health until the traumatic event

vignette: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.
diagnosis: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81) or F33.3 (Depression with psychotic features)
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette carefully.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Presenting complaint:
- "I think someone has been poisoning me at home"

Timeline:

- Coincided with job loss at local arcade

Symptoms identified:

- Persecutory delusion: believes mother is poisoning his food
- Persecutory delusion: believes parents are planning to kill him and replace him
- Delusion of reference: believes video game characters are his parents in disguise trying to "get into his head"
- Paranoid behavior: keeping shades drawn, stopped eating dinner
- Incorporated the doctor into his delusional system (believes doctor is working with parents to kill him)

2. Hallucinations:
- Auditory hallucinations: hears parents whispering through vents planning to kill him
- Auditory hallucinations even when parents are not present (hears them at the store)

3. Negative symptoms/depressive symptoms:
- Hypersomnia (sleeping from 7 PM to 12 PM - approximately 17 hours)
- Low energy
- Low motivation
- Problems with concentration
- Social withdrawal (remains in room)

4. Behavioral changes:
- Paranoid behavior
- Avoidance of food prepared by mother
- Social withdrawal
- Ran out of doctor's office mid-exam

Duration:
- Approximately 2.5 months total
- More than 1 month but less than 6 months

Stressors:
- Recent job loss

Rule-outs:
- Denied illicit substance use (UDS negative)
- Denied recent head injury
- Denied seizure
- No prior similar episodes
- Denied suicidal/homicidal ideation, plan, or intent


- No guns in home

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

The clinical picture shows clear psychotic features—multiple delusions and auditory hallucinations—alongside negative symptoms spanning 2.5 months. Schizophreniform disorder fits well given the symptom duration falls within the 1-6 month window. He demonstrates multiple first-rank symptoms: persecutory delusions, auditory hallucinations, and negative symptoms like avolition and social withdrawal.

Other diagnoses don't align as well. Brief psychotic disorder requires symptoms to resolve within a month, but his have persisted for 2.5 months. Schizophrenia would need six months of symptoms including prodromal features, which he hasn't reached yet—though this could be his trajectory. Delusional disorder doesn't fit because he has prominent hallucinations. The negative urine drug screen and absence of medical explanations support a primary psychotic disorder rather than substance-induced or medical causes. Condition** - no medical history or neurological findings to suggest this, though additional evaluation would be warranted to completely exclude it.

Given the 2.5-month symptom duration with clear psychotic features (delusions and hallucinations) alongside some negative symptoms, schizophreniform disorder appears most likely. If symptoms persist beyond six months, the diagnosis would shift to schizophrenia. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features remains a secondary consideration given the depressive components, though the psychotic symptoms seem primary rather than mood-dependent. Unspecified schizophrenia spectrum disorder could apply if the presentation remains unclear, and adjustment disorder warrants consideration given the recent job loss stressor. withdrawal) and a 2.5-month timeline. The depressive features—hypersomnia, fatigue, poor concentration, reduced motivation—likely represent negative symptoms rather than a primary mood disorder, given how the psychosis dominates the clinical picture.

My top diagnostic considerations are Schizophreniform Disorder as the leading diagnosis, with Schizophrenia as a possibility if symptoms extend beyond six months. Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features remains on the differential but seems secondary to the psychotic presentation. and Delusional Disorder doesn't fit well either since there are hallucinations and other psychotic symptoms beyond just delusions.

My final ranking: Schizophreniform Disorder is the primary consideration given the 2.5-month timeline. Schizophrenia could be emerging if symptoms persist. I'd also consider Unspecified Schizophrenia Spectrum Disorder as a fallback, Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features given the mood component, and Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum Disorder if the presentation doesn't align perfectly with standard criteria.

vignette: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.
diagnosis: Polysubstance use disorder, severe (F19.20); Alcohol use, with unspecified alcohol induced disorder (i.e. Beer Pantomania) (F10.99)

vignette: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. Collin’s wife states, “he gets angry of the smallest things.” She goes on to say, “I have to help him get to the bathroom because he is incontinent in the bed very night now”, stating she also has to bath the patient because he can’t find his way around the bathroom. Finally, Collin’s wife states “he goes around making things up when we get around family, sometimes just inventing stuff on the whim, like saying he is making additions to the house or buying a new car, when that is both not true and has nothing to do with the conversation.
diagnosis: Alcohol induced Korsakov’s Syndrome (F10.26); Persistent depressive disorder (F34.1)
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette carefully.

**Key Clinical Information Extracted:**

Demographics:
- 71-year-old male
- Remote history of alcohol use disorder (sober 6 years)
- Heavy alcohol use from age 28-65 (37 years of heavy use)
- Multiple hospitalizations for alcohol withdrawal
- Medical complications: acute liver failure, permanent gait abnormalities

Presenting Concerns:
- Family reports patient is "changing"
- Wandering behavior - 3 episodes in past month, nocturnal, into cold weather inappropriately dressed
- Patient has impaired recall of these events (remembers being brought inside but not going outside)

Cognitive/Functional Decline:
- Can't find way around the kitchen (executive dysfunction, spatial disorientation)
- Forgets to turn off stove burners
- Caused a kitchen fire a couple months ago
- Can't find way around the bathroom
- Requires assistance with bathing
- Timeline: Changes noticed starting about 2 years ago

Neurological:
- No acute abnormalities on CT scan
- No stroke indication
- No known falls
- No family history of dementia, Parkinson's, or Huntington's disease
- Has permanent gait abnormalities from alcohol use

Psychiatric Symptoms:
- Depressed mood (started ~2 years ago)
- Low motivation
- Anhedonia
- Passive suicidal ideation (past month)
- Irritability ("gets angry over smallest things")

Other Symptoms:
- Urinary incontinence (nightly)
- Confabulation ("making things up" around family, inventing stories about making house additions or buying a car that are not true and unrelated to conversation)

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

1. **Alcohol-Induced Major Neurocognitive Disorder (Alcohol-Related Dementia)**
The patient has:
- 37 years of heavy alcohol use
- Medical complications from alcohol (liver failure)


- Progressive cognitive decline over 2 years with memory loss and impaired executive function
- Significant functional deterioration in daily activities
- Confabulation, which is characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome and indicates damage to memory systems from chronic alcohol exposure
- Gait disturbance potentially stemming from cerebellar atrophy or prior Wernicke encephalopathy

The confabulation pattern is particularly significant—it's a classic marker of Korsakoff syndrome within the Wernicke-Korsakoff spectrum. While Wernicke's typically presents acutely with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia,

Korsakoff syndrome manifests with confabulation and anterograde amnesia. The appropriate DSM-5-TR diagnosis would be F10.27 for alcohol-induced major neurocognitive disorder with the amnestic-confabulatory type.

Additionally, there's a 2-year history of depressed mood with anhedonia, reduced motivation, and passive suicidal ideation. The irritability and low engagement could represent a separate Major Depressive Disorder, though mood symptoms frequently overlap with neurocognitive presentations, making it difficult to determine whether depression is independent or secondary to the cognitive decline.

The clinical picture—urinary incontinence, gait problems, and cognitive deterioration without acute CT findings—also raises consideration of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus, which presents with the classic triad of gait disturbance, incontinence, and dementia. While this is primarily a neurological rather than psychiatric diagnosis, it's worth noting in the differential. Given the patient's age of 71, vascular contributions to cognitive decline should also be considered as part of the overall neurocognitive picture. Alcohol-Induced Major Neurocognitive Disorder, Amnestic-Confabulatory Type (F10.26) fits best given the chronic heavy drinking history, confabulation pattern characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome, and gait disturbances. Even though the patient achieved sobriety 6 years ago, the persistent and progressive nature of this condition means the diagnosis remains valid—Korsakoff syndrome doesn't resolve simply with abstinence. The specific code depends on whether perceptual disturbances are present, but F10.26 captures the core presentation without additional features. The depressive symptoms warrant a separate diagnosis since they emerged alongside the cognitive decline. Major Depressive Disorder, single episode seems fitting given the suicidal ideation and severity. I should consider whether these are independent of the neurocognitive disorder or manifestations of it, but coding them separately captures the clinical presentation more completely.

For my final diagnostic formulation: F10.27 captures the alcohol-induced amnestic-confabulatory presentation with Korsakoff syndrome features—the confabulation, memory loss, heavy drinking history, and gait disturbance all align. F32.2 addresses the depressive symptoms with suicidal ideation as a distinct but concurrent condition. F10.26 seems most appropriate for the amnestic-confabulatory presentation. Major Depressive Disorder remains relevant given the 2-year history of anhedonia, low motivation, and depressed mood. Vascular or Alzheimer's-type neurocognitive disorders should be considered as differential diagnoses, particularly if neuroimaging shows relevant findings. The alcohol use disorder itself is in sustained remission after 6 years of abstinence. The primary diagnosis should be **F10.26** for alcohol-induced amnestic disorder (Korsakoff syndrome). Secondary diagnoses include **F32.2** for the severe depressive episode, **F01.51** for vascular dementia with behavioral disturbance as a differential consideration, and **F02.81** for dementia related to other medical conditions. **F10.21** captures the alcohol use disorder itself in sustained remission. I need to verify the precise coding distinctions—F10.26 specifically denotes alcohol dependence with persisting amnestic disorder, while F10.27 applies to alcohol-induced persisting dementia, and F10.97 relates to unspecified alcohol use patterns.

Looking at the clinical presentation more carefully: the memory gaps, executive dysfunction affecting navigation and safety awareness, prominent confabulation, functional decline, gait disturbance, and incontinence paint a picture broader than isolated amnesia. This constellation suggests a major neurocognitive disorder rather than pure amnestic syndrome, making F10.27 potentially more fitting. Yet the confabulation pattern is distinctly characteristic of Korsakoff presentation, which points back toward F10.26.

Considering that Korsakoff syndrome can evolve into more diffuse cognitive impairment across multiple domains, I'm settling on F10.26 given how prominently confabulation features in this case. The gait abnormality and incontinence also raise the possibility of normal pressure hydrocephalus, but since the question limits to F-codes, that differential doesn't change the coding approach here.

The secondary diagnoses worth considering include major depression with passive suicidal ideation over the past month (F32.2), vascular dementia given his age and alcohol-related cardiovascular risk factors (F01.51), and dementia from other classified conditions like NPH if that's the underlying etiology (F02.81).

Regarding alcohol use disorder in sustained remission for six years—this remains a relevant psychiatric diagnosis despite remission status, capturing important historical context. However, I should also explore whether unspecified dementia codes (F03.90 or F03.91) might be more appropriate if the specific etiology remains unclear, or whether Alzheimer's type dementia warrants consideration in the differential.

My final diagnostic list prioritizes alcohol-induced major neurocognitive disorder as the primary concern given the clinical presentation, followed by major depressive disorder, vascular dementia with behavioral features, dementia in other classified diseases, and the historical alcohol use disorder in remission. I need to verify the DSM-5-TR coding conventions for substance-induced neurocognitive disorders to ensure accuracy. with my final answer. The key codes are F10.26 for the alcohol-induced neurocognitive disorder with confabulation, F32.2 for the severe depression, F01.51 for vascular dementia with behavioral disturbance, F02.81 for dementia in other diseases with behavioral disturbance, and F10.21 for alcohol use disorder in sustained remission.

Looking back at the presentation, the confabulation really stands out as the defining feature—it's characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome. Combined with decades of heavy drinking, the gait problems suggesting past cerebellar or Wernicke involvement, and the memory loss, this clearly indicates alcohol-induced neurocognitive disorder. The dep

The depressive symptoms are also important and need their own diagnosis given the suicidal ideation. I should consider whether F10.27 (persisting dementia) fits better than F10.26 (amnestic-confabulatory type). The patient shows both memory impairment with confabulation and broader cognitive dysfunction like executive problems with navigation and forgetting the stove, which could suggest the wider cognitive decline of F10.27. But the confabulation remains the most striking feature, pointing toward F10.26 as the classic Korsakoff presentation. In actual clinical settings, Korsakoff syndrome often progresses into broader alcoholic dementia, so the codes overlap somewhat. I'll use F10.26 since it best captures the distinctive confabulatory pattern, though F10.27 would also work.

I should also weigh whether the depression stems from the neurocognitive disorder itself rather than being a separate major depressive disorder. That could point to F06.32 (depressive disorder due to another medical condition). But since the patient independently reports feeling depressed, I'll maintain F32.2 as a distinct diagnosis.

The remaining diagnoses address the vascular and other medical contributions to dementia, along with the alcohol use disorder in remission. F01.51 and F02.81 capture behavioral disturbances from vascular and other medical etiologies, while F10.21 reflects the severe alcohol use disorder that's currently sustained in remission.

The timeline is crucial here—the hallucinations emerged precisely when the patient began reducing alcohol intake 2 weeks ago, and they've persisted even 5 days after the last drink. Yet the first-rank symptoms like thought insertion and negative commentary hallucinations, combined with the documented manic episode requiring hospitalization 2 years prior, point toward an underlying primary psychotic or mood disorder rather than simple withdrawal. I'm weighing whether this represents Bipolar I with psychotic features during a depressive phase, Schizoaffective Disorder, or an alcohol-induced presentation superimposed on an existing condition.

The diagnostic hierarchy matters significantly—alcohol use disorder with severe withdrawal is clearly established, but I need to determine if the current psychosis is fundamentally alcohol-driven or reflects an independent psychiatric illness. The temporal coincidence of symptom onset with alcohol reduction is notable, yet the quality and persistence of the psychotic features suggest something more primary.

The thought insertion and hallucinations could align with alcohol-induced psychosis, schizoaffective disorder, or a primary psychotic disorder—the timing relative to drinking changes is the key discriminator here. olar I seems most comprehensive given the prior manic episode and current depressive presentation with possible psychotic features, though the strong connection between alcohol use and psychosis warrants consideration of an alcohol-induced psychotic disorder. The final diagnostic picture includes Bipolar I Disorder, current depressed episode with psychotic features (F31.5), Severe Alcohol Use Disorder (F10.20), PTSD (F43.10), Alcohol-Induced Psychotic Disorder with Hallucinations (F10.251), and Schizoaffective Disorder, Depressive type (F25.1) as differential considerations.

The paranoid ideation about being attacked and harassed requires careful assessment—whether these represent delusions or legitimate concerns—and the thought insertion symptom is particularly notable since it typically appears in schizophrenia spectrum conditions rather than primary mood disorders. The alcohol use disorder remains clearly established, and the potential for alcohol withdrawal adds another layer to the clinical picture that needs monitoring. The patient's presentation suggests alcohol withdrawal is a significant factor given the timeline of 5 days since last use combined with their documented history of severe withdrawal episodes. F10.232 captures this more precisely than the uncomplicated code. vignette: Erin is a 16 year old girl that was brought to her pediatric for a routine health exam. Erin is a sophomore at the local high school, plays lacrosse and does ballet at the local arts theatre. Erin reports that she has had no problems with depressed, sad or hopeless mood symptoms, and denied problems with excessive worry or panic. She lives at home with her two mothers, older brother and their dog Fiji. The patient does report that she goes to the gym for about 3 hours each day of the week, during which she does about 2.5 hours of cardiovascular training. She states she skip lunch on most days, has a sliced apple for breakfast, and take her dinner to her bedroom to slowly eat the vegetable portion of dinner (only) over a period of about 3 hours. Menarche was at age 13.5, but she has missed 3 of her last periods. She reports a lot of gastric reflex, and its wakes her up at night time. She also reports “I don’t really have bowel movements anymore, so I take a laxative in the morning and at night time.” She aims to eat less than 1000 calories in a day.
diagnosis: Anorexia nervosa, restrictive type (F50.01)
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical vignette carefully to extract relevant information and develop a diagnostic formulation.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 16-year-old female
- Sophomore in high school
- Active in lacrosse and ballet

Living situation:
- Lives with two mothers, older brother, and dog
- Stable home environment indicated

Presenting symptoms and behaviors:

1. Eating behaviors:
- Skips lunch most days
- Breakfast: only a sliced apple
- Dinner: takes only vegetable portion to bedroom, eats slowly over 3 hours
- Aims to eat less than 1000 calories per day (severe caloric restriction)

2. Exercise behaviors:
- Goes to gym for about 3 hours every day
- Does about 2.5 hours of cardiovascular training daily
- Also participates in lacrosse and ballet
- This represents excessive exercise

3. Menstrual history:
- Menarche at 13.5 years
- Has missed 3 of her last periods (secondary amenorrhea)
- This suggests physiological impact of malnutrition

4. GI symptoms:
- Reports significant gastric reflux (wakes her at night)
- Reports constipation ("I don't really have bowel movements anymore")
- Uses laxatives morning and night (laxative abuse)

5. Psychiatric symptoms denied:
- No depressed, sad, or hopeless mood
- No excessive worry or panic
- (Note: denial of psychiatric symptoms is common in anorexia nervosa)

6. Sleep:
- Disturbed by gastric reflux at night

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

Primary consideration: Anorexia Nervosa

DSM-5-TR criteria for Anorexia Nervosa:
A. Restriction of energy intake relative to requirements, leading to a significantly low body weight in the context of age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health. - YES (severe caloric restriction <1000 cal/day, skipping meals, eating only vegetables)


B. Intense fear of gaining weight or of becoming fat, or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight. - Inferred from the compulsive exercise regimen (3+ hours daily), rigid dietary restriction, and twice-daily laxative use, all suggesting active weight control behaviors. C. Disturbance in the way one's body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight. - Not directly articulated but the restrictive and compensatory behaviors imply body image disturbance. The secondary amenorrhea (missing 3 periods) represents a clear physiological consequence of severe nutritional deficit and hypothalamic suppression.

Additional physical markers of malnutrition include constipation from inadequate caloric intake and gastric reflux potentially stemming from delayed gastric emptying. The laxative misuse twice daily is significant—while she doesn't report binge eating episodes, the DSM-5-TR criteria for binge-eating/purging type includes purging behaviors such as laxative misuse independent of binge eating. This would classify her presentation as the binge-eating/purging subtype rather than the restricting type.

Without her actual weight or BMI, I'm relying on the secondary amenorrhea as a strong indicator of significant underweight status and malnutrition. The primary diagnosis appears to be Anorexia Nervosa, Binge-eating/Purging type, given the combination of severe restriction, compulsive exercise, and regular purging through laxatives. I should also consider whether Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting type might apply if the laxative use is determined to be less central to her presentation.

Other possibilities include atypical anorexia nervosa if her weight doesn't meet the "significantly low" threshold, though her amenorrhea suggests otherwise. Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder seems less fitting given the apparent weight and shape preoccupation driving her behaviors. Bulimia Nervosa is unlikely without documented binge episodes.

The most compelling diagnosis remains Anorexia Nervosa, Binge-eating/Purging type, given the combination of severe restriction, compulsive exercise, and laxative misuse as a purging mechanism. The secondary amenorrhea further supports significant physiological compromise from the eating disorder. While she denies mood or anxiety concerns, these frequently accompany eating disorders and may be minimized or unrecognized by the patient. I need to clarify whether the laxative use represents genuine constipation management or intentional purging for weight control. The constipation itself likely stems from her severe restriction, but taking laxatives twice daily suggests compensatory behavior rather than medical necessity. Given her pattern of multiple weight-control strategies—extreme caloric restriction and excessive exercise—using laxatives for weight management fits more logically with her overall presentation.

The DSM-5-TR criteria support Binge-Eating/Purging type when purging behaviors occur regularly over three months, even without concurrent binge episodes. Since she demonstrates recurrent laxative misuse during this timeframe, this subtype applies.

The differential includes Restricting type if laxative use were incidental, Bulimia Nervosa if binge episodes were primary, and ARFID or Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder if the clinical picture didn't meet full anorexia criteria—but her presentation clearly aligns with the Binge-Eating/Purging subtype.

2. Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting type - F50.01
3. Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder (Atypical Anorexia Nervosa) - F50.89
4. Bulimia Nervosa - F50.2
5. Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder - F50.82

vignette: Amber is a 37 year old woman, that comes to the emergency room with a chief complaint of “I just want to die.” Amber is well known to this emergency room, sometimes coming to the emergency room with suicidal thinking and plans more than 10 times a week. She reports extensive trauma history, including surviving sexual abuse as a adolescent at home, but then also surviving intimate partner violence in subsequent relationships in her adult hood. She reports “constant” flashbacks, nightmares, and hypervigilance, and now avoids any places where “Im the only woman in the room.” The patient reports her current suicidal thoughts and plan to overdose on all of her medications at home is due to “my girlfriend broke up with me out of the blue; she said I’m too much to handle.” The patient reports present mood of “pissed off”, but denied any recent problems or changes in appetite, energy, motivation or enjoying activities she typically enjoys. Denied recent or past mania or psychosis, and she denied problems with heavy alcohol use or street drug use. She acknowledges that “none of my family talk to me anymore; I only had my girlfriend for support.
diagnosis: Borderline personality disorder (F60.3); Post traumatic stress disorder (F43.1)

vignette: Evan is a 62 year old white man, a Harvard Professor in Economics, with a multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use, but recently sober for approximately 7 months after completing substance rehabilitation in an outpatient settings. Evan presented to the emergency room after taking approximately ten 1 mg Klonopin in one setting, he states was “because I was tired and really wanted to go to sleep.” The patient indicates “I was not trying to kill myself” and “I regret taking that number of tablets at once.” He acknowledges recent discord with his wife, stating “I feel very afraid that she is going to leave me whenever we get into arguments, also indicating that after their most recent argument 2 days prior, he relapsed with alcohol use and drank about 6 standard drinks each of the last 2 days, and was intoxicated at the time of overdose. Patient reports “I used to be so active in teaching at Harvard. Now, I feel like I don’t have purpose”, stating that his department at Harvard has been assigning him less teaching or supervising obligations. The patient denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. He denied recent or past symptoms of mania or psychosis. The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He acknowledges that there has been a significant increase in difficulty concentrating on texts he used to be able to attend to without issue. He states “sometimes it feels like I’m walking through mud throughout the day”, and “I want to get back to enjoying things in life again.” He acknowledges “sometimes I find myself just crying, but I have no idea why.” He denied feelings of hopelessness or despair. He denied trauma history, nor symptoms of OCD or panic. On arrival to the emergency room, patient acknowledged that he sustained a fall at home, which lead to his coming to the emergency room for evaluation. The patient is noted to have left peri-orbital ecchymosis and small, well-healing abrasions to his forehead. A head CT in the emergency room reveal a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma. The patient denied headache or vision changes in the emergency room. The emergency room clinician completed paperwork for the patient to be admitted on an involuntary basis to inpatient psychiatry. The following day, a repeat head CT revealed the subdural hematoma appeared 5-7 mm in length, yet the patient continued to deny vision changes, headache, confusion or extremity weakness. The patient reports he has been taking Cymbalta for a history of depression for over 5 years, and denied an untoward side effects.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, moderate, recurrent F33.1; Alcohol use disorder, severe
difficulty: Medium given patient minimizing extent of depression and that overdose was suicide attempt, although endorsing neurovegetative, cognitive, motivation, etc symptoms of depression.
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette to develop a comprehensive differential diagnosis.

**Key Clinical Information Extraction:**

1. **Demographics:** 62-year-old white male, Harvard Professor in Economics

2. **Presenting Problem:** 
   - Overdose on approximately ten 1mg Klonopin tablets

   - Multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use

4. **Psychosocial Stressors:**
   - Marital discord - fears wife will leave during arguments
   - Loss of purpose - reduced teaching/supervising obligations at Harvard
   - Recent argument with wife 2 days prior triggered relapse

5. **Depressive Symptoms:**
   - Hypersomnia (14 hours/day, still tired)
   - Unintentional weight loss (~10 lbs in past month)
   - Difficulty concentrating (on texts he previously could handle)
   - Psychomotor retardation ("walking through mud")
   - Anhedonia ("I want to get back to enjoying things in life again")
   - Crying spells without clear reason
   - Loss of purpose/meaning
   - Denies hopelessness or despair

6. **Denied Symptoms:**
   - Denies active suicidal ideation, plans, or intent
   - Denies homicidal ideation
   - Denies mania or psychosis history
   - No history of trauma, OCD, or panic symptoms

7. **Medical/Physical Findings:**
   - Fall at home
   - Left peri-orbital ecchymosis
   - Small, well-healing forehead abrasions
   - Subdural hematoma (initially 2-3mm, increased to 5-7mm next day)
   - Denies headache, vision changes, confusion, extremity weakness

8. **Current Treatment:** Cymbalta (duloxetine) for depression, 5+ years

**Differential Diagnosis Analysis:**

1. **Major Depressive Disorder,

Recurrent, Moderate to Severe:**
   - Multiple depressive features present: hypersomnia, weight loss, concentration difficulties, psychomotor retardation, anhedonia, crying spells
   - Long-standing depression managed with Cymbalta for five years
   - Current symptoms suggest inadequate treatment response or breakthrough depression
   - Recent symptom onset indicates active episode

2. **Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe:**
   - Decades-long pattern of heavy drinking
   - Prior outpatient rehabilitation
   - Recent relapse following seven months of sobriety
   - Interpersonal conflict preceded the relapse
   - Severity criteria met based on extensive history

3. **Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder vs. Intoxication:**
   - Took 10mg of Klonopin in one sitting, representing benzodiazepine misuse
   - Klonopin access present but prescription status unclear
   - Could reflect isolated intoxication rather than established use disorder pattern

4. **Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood:**
   - Psychosocial stressors include marital conflict and work changes
   - However, depressive presentation appears more consistent with major depression than adjustment-related symptoms

5. **Alcohol-Induced Depressive Disorder:**
   - Depression occurring alongside active alcohol use
   - Depressive symptoms predate recent relapse, having been present during five years on Cymbalta
   - Current worsening may reflect alcohol's contribution to existing depression

6. **Unspecified Anxiety Disorder:**
   - Fear of abandonment by wife, though insufficient symptoms to specify a particular anxiety disorder. This could also be related to personality features

7. **Personality Disorder Considerations:**
   - Abandonment fears suggest possible borderline features
   - Insufficient data for definitive diagnosis

**Final Differential Diagnosis (Top 5):**

1. **Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, Moderate** (F33.1)
   - Persistent depressive symptoms despite current treatment with hypersomnia, weight loss, anhedonia, psychomotor retardation, and concentration difficulties
   - Recurrent pattern with five-year treatment history

2. **Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe** (F10.20)
   - Decades-long history with prior rehabilitation and recent relapse
   - Significant functional impairment

3. **

Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder** (F13.10)
   - Single 10mg Klonopin dose raises question of whether this represents acute intoxication or emerging misuse pattern
   - The benzodiazepine overdose warrants consideration in the diagnostic picture

Reviewing the relevant ICD-10 codes: alcohol use disorder severe maps to F10.20, major depressive disorder recurrent moderate to F33.1, and sedative/hypnotic use disorder mild to F13.10.

The clinical presentation suggests major depressive disorder recurrent moderate as the primary diagnosis given the constellation of depressive symptoms and documented history. Alcohol use disorder severe is supported by decades of use, prior treatment attempts, and current relapse. For the benzodiazepine component, the acute intoxication from the single Klonopin dose combined with ongoing misuse pattern points toward F13.229, capturing both the intoxication state and underlying use disorder. The severity of depression warrants consideration of F33.2 given the functional impairment and overdose attempt. Alcohol Use Disorder is clearly established at the severe level. The benzodiazepine overdose suggests either acute intoxication or possible misuse pattern with sedatives, which would code as F13.129 or F13.229 depending on whether a use disorder is present. Since alcohol intoxication was documented at the time of the overdose, this should be specified as F10.229 given the established severe use disorder. The primary diagnoses consolidate to Major Depressive Disorder (moderate to severe), Alcohol Use Disorder (severe), and the acute benzodiazepine intoxication event. The alcohol use disorder warrants a severe designation given the pattern of use and current intoxication. For the benzodiazepine exposure, I'm noting intoxication rather than use disorder since the presentation centers on acute overdose in context of the other substances. The alcohol intoxication code captures the current state alongside the underlying disorder. Anxiety symptoms remain present but unspecified without clearer diagnostic criteria, so I'm coding this conservatively. I should verify the ICD-10 codes align properly—F33.1 for the depression, F10.20 for alcohol severity, and F13.10 if documenting sedative-hypnotic involvement, though the acute intoxication codes may be more clinically relevant here. Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder, Mild to Moderate - F13.10 or F13.20. The alcohol intoxication should be coded as F10.229, and there's an unspecified anxiety disorder component (F41.9).

Looking at the depression more carefully, the clinical presentation suggests moderate severity rather than mild. The hypersomnia, significant weight loss over a short timeframe, concentration problems, psychomotor changes, anhedonia, and emotional distress are substantial symptoms. Though he denies hopelessness and hasn't expressed suicidal intent, the overall symptom burden and functional impact point toward F33.1 rather than a milder presentation.

Regarding the sedative misuse—taking 10 Klonopin while drinking appears to be an acute intoxication event rather than evidence of an established pattern. Without sufficient history of problematic use, I should code this as F13.929 for the intoxication itself. The final diagnoses would be Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, Moderate (F33.1); Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe (F10.20); Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Intoxication (F13.929); concurrent alcohol intoxication (F10.229); and Unspecified Anxiety Disorder (F41.9).

vignette: Melanie is an 11 year old girl who was brought to urgent care by her mother after being sent home from school for “using racial slurs.” Melanie is the product of a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy, vaginally delivered with normal APGAR (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration) score at birth. Melanie used her first word “Momma” around 48 months of age, and didn’t start noticing other children playing with her until about 6 years old. Even at 6 years old, Melanie would not respond to her name when called, often appearing like she was in a daydream, and would often do a lot of “rocking” or “spinning” when anxious. Melanie’s mother indicates “Melanie is a unique kid. She doesn’t really make good eye contact with me, her father or her friends, and seems to be overly focused on doing puzzles all day. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.
diagnosis: Autistic Disorder (F 84.0); Tourette Syndrome (F95.2)
